newsitem.title: UK: Patten warns China against using heavy hand.
newsitem.headline: Patten warns China against using heavy hand.

text.p: Hong Kong's last British governor Chris Patten warned China on Thursday not to use a heavy hand against any protests when it takes control of the colony next week.

"It's in everybody's interests to ensure that the arrangements for the handover are able to confirm Hong Kong's reputation for moderation and responsibility," the Financial Times quoted Patten as saying in an interview.
Hong Kong pro-democracy activists have said they plan demonstrations over abolition of the current legislature and its replacement at midnight on Monday by a Beijing-appointed body.

Patten also warned that a decision by most European Union countries to send ministers to the Chinese ceremony to swear in the planned provisional legislature would further encourage China to disregard international pressure on human rights.
Europe "fell apart" earlier this year on a U.N. human rights resolution criticising China, and "it may well go in several different directions on this too," Patten said.
Britain was accused on Thursday of inviting contempt by deciding to attend the swearing-in of the controversial Beijing-appointed legislature.

After caving in to Beijing pressure to allow more troops into Hong Kong before the handover, Britain climbed down again on Wednesday and decided to join the United States in sending representatives to the ceremony.
"If they do this, they just invite contempt," pro-democracy legislator Emily Lau told Radio Hong Kong. "What kind of message are they trying to send to the rest of the world?"
